column4: is there anything i can look at under hal-device-manager to see what a usb device is named under /dev, so i can mount it?
i have no audio in dapper, so i'm going to save my voice mail to my pmp and listen to it...if i can figure out how to mount it, now that nautilus is sucking.
then again, why would anyone want to play a proprietary format.
your device isn't mounted automatically? Can you please file a bug?
ehh...okay.  where?
also, the 'block.device' property in h-d-m shows you the device
could you also tell me how to mount it?
sure
but first I'm surprised that it isn't mounted automatically; https://launchpad.net/distros/ubuntu/+source/gnome-volume-manager/+filebug is a head-start for filing a bug
the full name *is* block.device'
just do 'dmesg' and look at the last few lines; it should be something like /dev/sda1 or /dev/sdb1
and 'pmount-hal /dev/sda1' (or whatever) will mount it
i already did that and saw nothing like that
you mean, the kernel does not even recognize your device? that's baad
i don't know what the device is called.
well, this is just the USB bus driver, but there's no mesage about the storage device on it
can you please pastebin your full dmesg?
that looks horribly incomplete :/
are you sure that there is a standard partition table on it?
yes, I know, but there's no sign of the kernel finding a partition table, let alone partitions
